dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so today, we're diving into something a little sobering, but super important. We're talking about the life insurance gap, especially for millennials.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, so today, we're diving into something a little sobering, but super important. We're talking about the life insurance gap, especially for millennials.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, that's, um, that's not exactly a light topic for a Tuesday, is it? But yeah, I'm all ears. What's the deal?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, that's, um, that's not exactly a light topic for a Tuesday, is it? But yeah, I'm all ears. What's the deal?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, a new survey from New York Life found that millennials with life insurance, they only have about $100,000 in coverage. But they actually *need* closer to $450,000. That's a huge, like, $352,000 shortfall.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, a new survey from New York Life found that millennials with life insurance, they only have about one hundred thousand dollars in coverage. But they actually need closer to four hundred fifty thousand dollars. That's a huge, like, three hundred fifty two thousand dollar shortfall.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Thats the sobering news from New York Lifes 2018 Life Insurance Gap Survey. Millennials with life insurance have an average of $100,000 in life insurance protection in place, enough to cover one fifth (22%) of their self-reported coverage needs of $452,000. Thats a coverage shortfall of $352,000.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Whoa. That's a massive gap. So, is it that millennials just don't *want* life insurance? Or what's, uh, what's going on there?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Whoa. That's a massive gap. So, is it that millennials just don't want life insurance? Or what's, uh, what's going on there?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: According to Brian Madgett from New York Life, it's not that they don't want it. It's more of a prioritization issue. I mean, they're juggling student loan debt, saving for their kids' education, and, you know, the big screen TV, a new car, even that daily coffee.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: According to Brian Madgett from New York Life, it's not that they don't want it. It's more of a prioritization issue. I mean, they're juggling student loan debt, saving for their kids' education, and, you know, the big screen T V, a new car, even that daily coffee.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its not an issue of Millennials not wanting to get life insurance; its more a prioritization issue, says Brian Madgett, who leads New York Lifes national life sales and its advanced planning group. The concept of taking care of their families and loved ones is in competition with the big screen tv, car and even that daily cup of coffee. Not to mention their student loan debtand the desire to save for their childrens education.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Okay, I totally get that. I mean, it's hard enough to balance all those things without adding another monthly payment to the mix.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, I totally get that. I mean, it's hard enough to balance all those things without adding another monthly payment to the mix.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? But the numbers are pretty stark. Millennials, anyone born between '81 and '96, are looking at a 78% shortfall.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? But the numbers are pretty stark. Millennials, anyone born between eighty one and ninety six, are looking at a seventy eight percent shortfall.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Millennialsanyone born between 1981 and 1996, so ages 22 to 37 this yearreport a 78% shortfall in life insurance coverage, according to the survey.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And how does that compare to, say, us Gen Xers, or even Baby Boomers? Are we all, like, equally bad at this?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And how does that compare to, say, us Gen Xers, or even Baby Boomers? Are we all, like, equally bad at this?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Actually, no. Gen Xers have a 48% shortfall, and Baby Boomers are down to 37%. So, millennials are definitely leading the pack in terms of, uh, needing more coverage.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Actually, no. Gen Xers have a forty eight percent shortfall, and Baby Boomers are down to thirty seven percent. So, millennials are definitely leading the pack in terms of, uh, needing more coverage.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By contrast, Gen Xers, born between 1965 and 1980, so 38 to 53 this yearreport a 48% coverage shortfall. ... Baby Boomers say they have $190,000 of coverage but need $300,000a 37% shortfall.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Hmm. So, what usually prompts people to finally get serious about this? Is there a trigger?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hmm. So, what usually prompts people to finally get serious about this? Is there a trigger?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, there are two big ones: buying a home and having kids. That's when it usually clicks for people that they need to replace their income if, you know, something happens.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, there are two big ones: buying a home and having kids. That's when it usually clicks for people that they need to replace their income if, you know, something happens.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Buying a home and having kids are the two big things that prompt people to get coverage.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: You know, my dad used to nudge my husband and me about term life insurance. And, uh, we eventually did get it once we had kids. It's like, you hear it, but you don't *hear* it until it's really relevant.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You know, my dad used to nudge my husband and me about term life insurance. And, uh, we eventually did get it once we had kids. It's like, you hear it, but you don't hear it until it's really relevant.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: I remember my dad nudging my husband and me to get term life insurance policies. We finally did when we had kids.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And itâ€™s crucial because if you have coverage through work, it often only pays out one or two years' salary. And it ends if you leave your job!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And it's crucial because if you have coverage through work, it often only pays out one or two years' salary. And it ends if you leave your job!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If you have life insurance coverage at work, keep in mind that that policy might pay only one- or two-years salary, and it will likely end if you leave your job.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Which is, like, not ideal if that's your only protection. So, what's the solution here? Term life? Is it really that expensive?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is, like, not ideal if that's your only protection. So, what's the solution here? Term life? Is it really that expensive?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Not at all! Term life is actually pretty cheap, especially if you get it when you're younger. For a healthy 35-year-old male, you're looking at about $250 a year for a $500,000 policy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Not at all! Term life is actually pretty cheap, especially if you get it when you're younger. For a healthy thirty five-year-old male, you're looking at about two hundred fifty dollars a year for a five hundred thousand dollar policy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For a healthy 35-year-old male, it would cost about $250 a year for a 20-year level term policy with a $500,000 death benefit, according to Term4sale.com, where you can run your own numbers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow, that's, uh, that's less than my daily coffee habit for a year!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow, that's, uh, that's less than my daily coffee habit for a year!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: See? And if you go out 30 years, until retirement, it's about $450 a year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: See? And if you go out thirty years, until retirement, it's about four hundred fifty dollars a year.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Or go out 30 years until retirement, for $450 a year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, um, the takeaway is: definitely don't just rely on your work policy, and shop around. Don't just take the first quote.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, um, the takeaway is: definitely don't just rely on your work policy, and shop around. Don't just take the first quote.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. Use a calculator to figure out what you need, and definitely check the financial strength of the insurer too. It's a big decision.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. Use a calculator to figure out what you need, and definitely check the financial strength of the insurer too. It's a big decision.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The American Institute of CPAs has a life insurance needs calculator to help you determine how much you really need. ... And make sure you assess the financial strength of the insurance company before you buy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's, uh, it's one of those things that's easy to put off, but really, really important. Thanks for the wake-up call, Host_A.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's, uh, it's one of those things that's easy to put off, but really, really important. Thanks for the wake-up call, Host A.
